case_name: Messrs. Durga Dutt Chandi Prasad v. State of Bihar

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 170 to 172 of 1959 are appeals by special leave from decisions of the Board of Revenue, Bihar dated August 20, 1953/September 3, 1953, and August 30, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 170 to 172 of 1959. Appeals by special leave from the decision dated August 20, 1953/September 3, 1953, and August 30, 1954, of the Board of Revenue, Bihar at Patna in Reference Cases Nos. 461 and 462 of 1952 and 430 of 4954, respectively.

facts.text: The firm of Messrs. Durga Dutt Chandi Prasad carried on a business of dealing in raw jute at Sahebganj in Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: The firm of Messrs. Durga Dutt Chandi Prasad, appellant in these appeals, carried on a business of dealing in several kinds of goods but mostly in raw jute at Sahebganj in Bihar.

facts.text: The firm was registered as a dealer under s. 4 of the Bihar Sales Tax Act, 1944, with effect from July 1, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: It was registered as a dealer under s. 4 of the Bihar Sales Tax Act, 1944, with effect from July 1, 1946.

facts.text: The firm was assessed to sales tax for periods commencing October 1, 1947 to March 31, 1950, including purchases on behalf of Raigarh Jute Mills and Bengal Jute Mills outside Bihar and despatches to own firm in Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: For three periods, commencing from October 1, 1947 and ending on March 31, 1950, it was assessed to sales tax on its turnover of the relevant periods, which consisted inter alia of purchases alleged, to have made on behalf of two other jute mills outside Bihar, namely, the Raigarh Jute Mills and the Bengal Jute Mills, and also of dispatches of jute said to have been made to the dealers own firm in Calcutta for sale in Calcutta.

facts.text: For assessment period October 1, 1947 to March 31, 1948, appellant claimed deduction of Rs. 6,58,880-5-9 for purchases on behalf of two jute mills and Rs. 1,62,662-13-3 for despatches to own firm in Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment period commencing on October 1, 1947 and ending on March 31, 1948 the appellant claimed a deduction of  a  Rs. 6,58,880-5-9 on the ground that the said amount represented purchases made on behalf of the aforesaid two jute mills, and  b  Rs. 1,62,662-13-3 being despatches of jute made to the dealers own firm in Calcutta.

facts.text: Similar deduction claims made by appellant for period April 1, 1948 to March 31, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, for the next assessment period commencing on April 1, 1948 and ending on March 31, 1949 the appellant claimed a deduction of certain amounts  the exact amounts being irrelevant for our purpose  on the two grounds mentioned above from the relevant turnover.

facts.text: For period April 1, 1949 to March 31, 1950, appellant claimed similar deductions plus Rs. 1,00,513-11-9 for sale of mustard seed to Messrs. Panna Lal Binjraj.

anchor.surface_text: For the third period of assessment commencing on April 1, 1949 and ending on March 31, 1950 a similar claim was made. But for this period there was an additional claim with regard to the sale of mustard seed worth Rs. 1,00,513- 119 to Messrs. Panna Lal Binjraj for which the appellant claimed a deduction.

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer disallowed claims for first two periods on June 7, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: On June 7, 1951 the Sales Tax Officer concerned disallowed the claim of the appellant for the first two periods

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer disallowed claim for third period by order dated April 17, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: and by an order dated April 17, 1953, the claim for the third period was also disallowed.

facts.text: Appeals to Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes, Bihar dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then preferred appeals under the relevant provisions of the Act. These appeals were heard by the Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes,, Bihar, and were dismissed by him.

facts.text: Revisions to Board of Revenue dismissed on August 20, 1953 and September 3, 1953 for first two periods.

anchor.surface_text: Then the appellant filed applications in revision under s. 24 of the Act to the Board of Revenue, Bihar. The Board by its orders dated August 20, 1953, and September 3, 1953, dismissed the petitions of revision relating to the first two periods

facts.text: Board dismissed revision for third period on April 30, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: and by its orders dated April 30, 1954, also dismissed the petition of revision relating to the third period.

facts.text: Board refused to state case to High Court under s.25(1) for all periods.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 25 1  of the Act-the appellant moved the Board to state a case to the High Court of Patna on certain questions of law which, According to the appellant, arose out of the orders passed. The Board, however, refused to state a case

facts.text: Board order refusing reference for third period dated August 30, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: the leave granted being confined to the order of the Board of Revenue dated August 30, 1954, by which the Board decided that no questions of law arose for a reference to the High Court.

facts.text: High Court dismissed applications to direct Board to state case for first two periods on November 17, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then moved the High Court for requiring the Board to state a case on the questions of law which, according to the appellant, arose out of the orders passed with regard to the first two periods of assessment. By an order dated November 17, 1954,

facts.text: High Court directed Board to state case on mustard seed question for third period.

anchor.surface_text: On a similar application made by the appellant to the High Court with regard to the third period of assessment, the High Court directed the Board of Revenue to state a case on the following question Whether the petitioner is entitled to claim a deduction on account of sale of mustard seed to the extent of Rs. 1,00,513-11-9 to Messrs. Panna Lal Binjraj

facts.text: High Court answered mustard seed question against appellant on January 21, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: By an order dated January 21, 1957 the High Court answered the question against the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant applied for special leave on February 17, 1955 for first two periods, granted December 23, 1955 from Board revision orders.

anchor.surface_text: On February 17,1955, the appellant made an application to this Court for special leave to appeal from the orders of the Board of Revenue passed on the two applications in revision as respects the first two periods. This Court granted the leave prayed for by an order dated December 23, 1955.

facts.text: Appellant applied for special leave on April 12, 1955 for third period, granted December 23, 1955 confined to Board order August 30, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: With regard to the third period of assessment regarding which the High Court had directed the Board to state a case on a particular question of law and had actually answered it, the appellant again made an application for special leave to appeal on April 12, 1955, and this Court granted leave to the appellant by an order dated December 23, 1955,

facts.text: No special leave sought or granted against High Court orders.

anchor.surface_text: No application was made for leave to appeal, nor was any leave granted, with regard to the subsequent orders made by the Board refusing to state a case or the orders of the High Court refusing the application of the appellant to direct the Board to state a case.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeals without going into merits as special leave not properly granted to bypass High Court.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, special leave was not properly given in these cases and we would accordingly dismiss the appeals with costs, without going into merits.

facts.text: Board found that despatches of jute outside Bihar and purchases for mills outside Bihar were concluded by findings of fact and not open to challenge.

anchor.surface_text: The Board expressed the view that the two questions, namely,  1  whether the despatch of jute outside the State of Bihar was a sale within the meaning of the Act and  2  whether the purchases said to have been made on behalf of the two mills outside Bihar were liable to tax, were both concluded by findings of fact arrived at by the competent authorities on relevant materials in the record and were no longer open to challenge.

facts.text: High Court found no questions of law arose for first two periods.

anchor.surface_text: With regard to two of the assessment orders the High Court held that no questions of law arose at all

facts.text: High Court held petitioner not entitled to deduction for mustard seed sale as no mention in registration certificate for manufacture.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the petitioner was not entitled to deduction of the amount of the price of mustard seed sold to Messrs. Panna Lal Binjraj for the purpose of manufacture because there is no mention in the certificate of registration granted to Messrs. Panna Lal Binjraj that mustard seed could be sold to them for the purpose of manufacture free of tax.

issues.text: whether as a matter of practice of this Court, the appellant is entitled to be heard on merits in the three appeals when special leave was neither asked for nor granted in respect of the subsequent orders of the High Court relating to the assessments in question which have now become final between the parties thereto

anchor.surface_text: On the facts stated above the question which has arisen is whether as a matter of practice of this Court, the appellant is enticed to be heard on merits in the three appeals when special leave was neither asked for nor granted in respect of the subsequent orders of the High Court relating to the assessments in question which have now become final between the parties thereto. In other words, the question is- whether the High Court should be allowed to be by-passed in the manner sought to be done by the appellant in these three appeals?

issues.text: whether the High Court should be allowed to be by-passed in the manner sought to be done by the appellant in these three appeals

In other words, the question is- whether the High Court should be allowed to be by-passed in the manner sought to be done by the appellant in these three appeals? The position is quite clear.

issues.text: whether in the circumstances under consideration, it is a proper exercise of discretion to allow the appellant to have resort to the power of this Court under Art. 136

anchor.surface_text: The question before us is not whether we have the power undoubtedly, we have the power, but the question is whether in the circumstances under present consideration, it is a proper exercise of discretion to allow the appellant to have resort to the power of this Court under Art. 136. That question must be decided on the facts of each case, having regard to the practice of this Court and the limitations which this Court itself has laid down with regard to the exercise of its discretion under Art. 136.

arguments.claim: Court may reconsider propriety of special leave at appeal hearing stage even if granted earlier

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this as correct. In these cases leave was granted without hearing the respondents, and full materials in the record were not available nor placed before the Court when leave was granted. In Baldota Brothers v. Libra Mining Works this Court has pointed out that there is no distinction in the scope of the exercise of the power under Art. 136 at the stage of application for special leave and at the stage when the appeal is finally disposed of, and it is open to the Court to question the propriety of the leave granted even at the time of the hearing of the appeal.

arguments.claim: Special leave under Art.136 should not be used to bypass High Court where its orders on s.25 refusals or decisions are final

anchor.surface_text: On the facts stated above the question which has arisen is whether as a matter of practice of this Court, the appellant is entitled to be heard on merits in the three appeals when special leave was neither asked for nor granted in respect of the subsequent orders of the High Court relating to the assessments in question which have now become final between the parties thereto. In other words, the question is- whether the High Court should be allowed to be by-passed in the manner sought to be done by the appellant in these three appeals?

arguments.claim: Scheme of Bihar Sales Tax Act ss.23,24,25 channels questions of law to High Court to avoid conflict; Art.136 does not override to bypass
Art.136 discretion exercised sparingly only in exceptional cases with special circumstances showing substantial injustice

anchor.surface_text: The question before us is not whether we have the power undoubtedly, we have the power, but the question is whether in the circumstances under present consideration, it is a proper exercise of discretion to allow the appellant to have resort to the power of this Court under Art. 136. That question must be decided on the facts of each case, having regard to the practice of this Court and the limitations which this Court itself has laid down with regard to the exercise of its discretion under Art. 136.

arguments.claim: No special circumstances exist here to justify Art.136; appellant trying to bypass final High Court orders

anchor.surface_text: Are there any such circumstances in the appeals before us? The answer must clearly be in the negative. Under the scheme of the Act which we had adverted to earlier, it is not open to the appellant to contest either the findings of fact arrived at by the assessing authorities.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, special leave was number properly given in these cases and we would accordingly dismiss the appeals with costs, without going into merits.

anchor.surface_text: laim for the third period was also disallowed. The appellant then preferred appeals under the relevant provisions of the Act. These appeals were heard

edges.explanation: The Bihar Finance Act No.11 of 1949 is directly referenced in the span defining the issue of entitlement to deduction for sales of mustard seed to a registered dealer.
Section 4 imposes tax on sales within the Act, addressing whether despatch outside Bihar is a sale within the meaning of the Act.
Section 4 as charging section imposing tax liability on dealers addresses whether purchases liable to tax.
Section 4 liability based on gross turnover addresses claims for deductions in computing turnover.
Section 5 Bihar Sales Tax Act is clustered with the issue of whether despatch of jute outside Bihar constitutes a sale within the meaning of the Act, indicating the section addresses this issue
Section 5 Bihar Sales Tax Act is clustered with the issue of entitlement to deduction for sales of mustard seed to registered dealers, indicating the section addresses this issue
Argument a11 explicitly discusses the scheme of Bihar Sales Tax Act ss.23,24,25, which is grounded in Section 23 (c5) providing finality to assessments and orders.
Section 23 (c5) provides finality to assessments except per s.25, supporting h1's dismissal without merits in context of improper Art.136 special leave.
c9 specializes c11's general Art.136 practice by providing natural justice violation as bypass exception.
c9's doctrine on natural justice violations enabling Art.136 addresses whether proper exercise of discretion under Art.136 in the circumstances.
